name: Licensing and Social Responsibility - Scotland
minimumTimeMessage: Under the Licensing [Scotland] Act 2005 you are required by law to complete 2 hours of training to ensure you are fully aware of your responsibilities under the Act.

questions.text: Which five of the following are the licensing objectives?

choices.choice: Preventing the sale of cheap alcohol.
Reducing the amount of licensed premises.

questions.text: Who is responsible for establishing a Local Licensing Forum?
The Licensing Standards Officer is appointed to...

choices.choice: elect the members of the Local Licensing Forum
provide training for staff regarding the sale of alcohol according to the Act
supervise compliance of Personal Licence Holders

questions.text: Identify the three types of licence issued under the Act?

Occasional Licenses can be issued to...

choices.choice: A Personal Licence lasts for 10 years but holders must  retrain every 5 years
A Personal Licence lasts for 5 years but holders must retrain every 3 years
A Personal Licence lasts for 3 years but holders must retrain every year

questions.text: Premises Licence applications are submitted to...
Which four of the following are mandatory conditions necessary to apply for a Premises Licence?

choices.choice: Only Personal Licence Holders may sell alcohol
Alcohol must be sold at a set price
Tap water must be made available at a reasonable price
All alcohol must be sold in accordance with the operating plan
Only trained staff may sell alcohol

questions.text: What are licensed hours?

choices.choice: The hours stated in your operating plan when open to the public
The hours stated in your operating plan when selling alcohol

questions.text: The law states it is an offence...

choices.choice: to be on a licensed premises without a personal licence
to be on a licensed premises while drunk and incapable

to ask a person who is not drunk to leave the premise
to sell alcohol to a person who is drunk

During what hours, at what locations and to what strength of alcohol you may sell
During what hours, at what location and to whom you may sell alcohol

questions.text: Drinking up time allows the customers to drink outside of licensed hours...
What is a Premises Licence?

choices.choice: A licence stating a premises can store alcohol
A licence authorising the consumption of alcohol in the licensed premises
A licence authorising a premises to sell alcohol

questions.text: The role of a Licensing Standards Officer [LSO] is to...

choices.choice: ensure the quality of alcohol based products sold in a premises
supervise the compliance of the premises licence holder
carry out training for staff new to the licensed trade

questions.text: You may serve alcohol in your workplace during what hours?

choices.choice: The hours stated in your premises operating plan

questions.text: Alcohol for legal purposes is defined as...

choices.choice: A drink with more than 0.3% alcohol at the time of sale
A drink with more than 0.4% alcohol at the time of sale
A drink with more than 0.5% alcohol at the time of sale

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an objective of the Licensing Act 2005?
Which of the following is an offence under the Licensing [Scotland] Act 2005?

choices.choice: It is an offence to obtain alcohol for a person who is drunk
It is an offence to drink alcohol with a person who is drunk
It is an offence to serve alcohol to a person who is drunk

questions.text: Which of these is not a type of licence that can be issued?
The 5 Licensing Objectives aim...

choices.choice: to ensure that alcohol is only consumed on licensed premises
to improve the environment for social drinking so that it is safer for all
to increase the number of licensed premises within Scotland

questions.text: What is MUP?
Which of the following best describes MUP?

choices.choice: It is against the law to sell alcohol any cheaper that 50p per 100ml in Scotland
It is against the law to sell alcohol any cheaper that 25p per unit in Scotland
It is not recommended to sell alcohol any cheaper that 50p per unit in Scotland
It is against the law to sell alcohol any cheaper that 50p per unit in Scotland

questions.text: It is a requirement that all staff who sell alcohol are aware of MUP legislation and do not sell alcohol at a price lower than is legal.
According to MUP legislation, a 750ml bottle of wine at 12% ABV must be sold for no less than...
All alcohol must be sold at or below its MUP.
What should you do if you or a colleague locate a specific item mentioned within a terrorist threat? (2 correct answers)

choices.choice: Do not touch, tilt or tamper with the item.
Notify the police immediately and follow the instructions given to you by them.

questions.text: Which of the following is an offence?

choices.choice: To allow a 15 year old to consume wine bought by an adult with a meal
To allow a 16 year old to consume wine bought by an adult with a meal
To allow a 17 year old to consume wine bought by an adult with a meal

questions.text: A child is defined as...

choices.choice: someone who is under 12 years of age
someone who is under 16 years of age
someone who is under 18 years of age

questions.text: It is not an offence to buy wine, beer, lager, cider or perry for a young person along with bar snacks supplied on the premises.
Which three of the following are legally accepted proof of age documents?
The purpose of the Test Purchasing is to ensure that individuals working in the licensed premises are...

dispensing alcohol to customers of the correct age
dispensing alcohol to customers in the correct quantities

questions.text: Which of the following should you accept as proof of age?

choices.choice: PASS card, valid passport, student card
Valid passport, driving licence, PASS card
Student card, valid passport, driving licence

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an offence?

To sell beer, wine, cider or perry to a young person along with a meal supplied on the premises
A young person buying beer, wine, cider or perry who is also eating a meal supplied by the premises

questions.text: When in doubt of a person's age you should...

choices.choice: request recommended proof of age before considering service
ask another member of staff to serve them

questions.text: A young person is classified as...

choices.choice: someone between the age of 14 and 18

questions.text: Which of these is NOT an accepted form of age identification?

Adults are authorised by police to buy alcohol for children and young people

A conflict strategy should include the following information?

slides.title: Welcome to Licensing and Social Responsibility

widget.content: LICENSING AND SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY
What will i cover?
welcome to

Welcome to Licensing and Social Responsibility. This module is designed to help you understand your legal and social responsibility in the supply and dispense of alcohol as a member of staff in the licensed trade. Throughout this module we will explore the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 and all the responsibilities associated with the act.

At the end of each section you will be asked some questions before progressing to the next section, at the end of the module there will be a final exam. You must take a total of two hours to complete the module before you are able to access the exam.

widget.content: Conflict in Your Workplace
The Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005
1.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
THE LICENSING
(SCOTLAND) ACT 2005

widget.name: TEXT. Main. State 1.
widget.content:
The Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 sets out the legislation and law relating to the sale of alcohol in Scotland. For the purpose of this act, alcohol is defined as the following:

Where the strength of an alcoholic drink is over 0.5% at the time of sale, it is classed as alcohol for the purposes of licensing law. Alcohol means spirits, wine, beer, cider or any other fermented, distilled or spirituous liquor.

While you do not need to know the full details of the new Act, it is important to explore and understand the areas in which you have a direct responsibility to uphold the law.

widget.name: TEXT. Main.
widget.content:
As a member of staff in the licensed trade, it is important that you are fully aware of the objectives of the Licensing [Scotland] Act 2005.

These objectives aim to improve the environment for social drinking so that it is safer and more welcoming for all. You play an important role in supporting these objectives.

widget.name: TEXT. Title.
widget.content: THE 5 LICENSING OBJECTIVES

widget.name: TEXT.1
widget.content: 1. Preventing crime and disorder

widget.name: TEXT.2
widget.content: 2. Securing public safety

widget.name: TEXT.4
widget.content:
4. Protecting and improving public
   health

widget.name: TEXT.3
widget.content: 3. Preventing public nuisance

widget.name: TEXT.5
widget.content: 5. Protecting children from harm

There are a number of key people involved in the administration of the Licensing [Scotland] Act 2005.

Select the icons below to find out more.
PEOPLE IN LICENSING

Local
Licensing
Forum

Licensing
Boards
LSO
Police

widget.mainContent: Each local authority must establish a Local Licensing Forum whose purpose is to regularly review the licensing system in the area and advise the Licensing Board of any areas of concern.

The administration of the licensing system lies with Licensing Boards made up of elected local council members for each local council area. Members of a licensing board must be trained to a set standard. Licensing Boards exist to approve and issue licences based on the statement of licensing policy for their area. The statement must promote the 5 licensing objectives, include details of local conditions and provide an assessment of overprovision.

The activities of your workplace will be determined by the decisions made by the Licensing Board in your area. Levels of provision are determined by the Licensing Board, and this could have an impact upon the granting of licences if it is deemed that there are enough "types" of a particular premises in the area.

Each council must appoint at least one LSO for their local area. The LSO is appointed to:

  • Provide advice, assistance and information on the Licensing Act.
  • Provide guidance and information on how the licensing objectives are being met in their area.
  • Act as a mediator between licence holders and interested parties in the event of disputes/disagreements.
  • Supervise compliance of premises licence holders. The LSO has the right to issue notices of non-compliance where appropriate.

An LSO has the power to enter any licensed premises in their area to carry out an inspection of the premises to ensure it is operating in accordance with the operating plan. They have the right to any information and documentation they require. Anyone working on the premises that refuses to assist the LSO commits an offence.

The police have the right to enter and inspect any licensed premises at any time. They can also issue a closure order if they believe that disorder in licenced premises is likely to occur and it's in the interest of public safety to do so.

Trading standards officers, environmental health officers, building standards officers, building planning officers and the fire service can visit your business at any time to ensure that your business is complying with the law It's a good idea to build up a good working relationship with the police and other statutory bodies.

widget.content:
The
three types
of licence available are...
Premises licence
Personal licence
Occasional licence

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
There are three types of licence issued under the Act.

Select the icons below to find out about each type of licence.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: TYPES OF LICENCE

widget.mainContent:
All premises that wish to supply alcohol must have a premises licence authorising them to sell alcohol. Any person, limited company, business partnership, or club may apply for a premises licence. These licences can run indefinitely but may be lapsed or revoked if certain conditions cease to apply. The conditions under which premises licences are granted will be covered later in the module.

Your premises licence or a certified true copy must be displayed prominently on the premises for all to see. Especially for inspection by a police constable or an LSO.

All licensed premises must be managed by a premises manager who must hold a personal licence. To gain a Personal Licence, you must submit an application along with your Personal Licence Holder certificate to your local licencing board. This licence allows the holder to supervise and authorise the sale of alcohol.

You must be 18 or over and hold a relevant licensing qualification. The licence lasts for 10 years, but holders must undertake training every five years. Personal licences are granted for the area in which the applicant lives.

An occasional licence authorises the sale of alcohol on premises not covered by a premises licence.

Occasional licences can be issued to the holder of a premises licence, the holder of a personal licence, or a representative of a voluntary organisation. Occasional licences last for a maximum of 14 days.

widget.content: follow these three steps...

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
In order to apply for a premises licence, you must submit an operating plan and carry out a risk assessment on your business activities. There are also a number of mandatory conditions which must be adhered to.

Select the icons below to find out more.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: PREMISES LICENCE

widget.name: TEXT.Operating Plan
widget.content:
Operating Plan

An operating plan must be in place before a premises licence can be granted, therefore all licensed premises must have such a plan which states:

  • whether alcohol is sold on or off the premises, or both
  • all activities that will take place on the premises, including food service, promotions and entertainment
  • the hours these activities will take place
  • the policy of children and young people
  • information on the premises manager
  • the operational plan will enable Licensing Boards to assess the level of provision as part of the application process

widget.name: TEXT.Risk Assessment
widget.content:
Risk Assessment

As part of the operating plan, a risk assessment of all business activities, and how any issues identified will be dealt with, should be completed by your manager. The following areas should be considered:

  • closing-time procedures
  • dispersal policy
  • age-related sales policy
  • promotions
  • refusal of service
  • communications within the premises
  • plans to manage any conflict, drunkenness and disorder
  • noise control
  • management of smoking

widget.name: TEXT.Premises Licence Conditions
widget.content: Premises Licence Conditions

widget.name: TEXT.Premises Licence Conditions
widget.content:
Having been granted a premises licence, there are certain mandatory conditions that must be adhered to in order to keep the licence valid.

All licences are subject to the following mandatory conditions:

widget.name: TEXT.Premises Licence Conditions
widget.content:
• all alcohol must only be sold in accordance with the operating plan
  • alcohol may not be sold if there is no premises manager - if a premises manager can no longer continue in that role, the Licensing Board must be notified within 7 days, and a new premises manager must be appointed within 6 weeks
  • alcohol may not be sold if there is no personal licence holder to authorise the sale of alcohol
  • only trained staff may sell alcohol
  • alcohol must be sold at a set price
  • tap water must be made available without charge
  • non-alcoholic drinks must be made available at reasonable prices

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Another key term you must be familiar with is licensed hours. These represent the hours, stated in your workplace operating plan, during which the sale and consumption of alcohol is legal.

You must ensure that you know the licensed hours for your workplace since it is an offence to sell, or allow alcohol to be sold, on licensed premises outside of your licensed hours.

It is also an offence to allow alcohol to be consumed on, or taken from, licensed premises outside of your licensed hours. However, you may allow your customers what is commonly known as 'drinking up time'.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: Licensed Hours

Therefore, the law states that it is not an offence to allow alcohol to be consumed...

  • within 15 minutes of the end of licensed hours, as long as the drink is sold within licensed hours.
  • in or taken from licensed premises if done so by someone residing or living on the premises, or by a guest of a resident.
  • with a meal within 30 minutes of the end of licensed hours, if sold during licensed hours for the purpose of consumption with a meal.

Anyone who continues drinking after the drinking up time has ended must be asked to stop drinking by a responsible member of your team, such as a manager. Talk to your premises manager about your own workplace licensed hours and 'drinking up time' policy.

widget.name: Title
widget.content: Offences

widget.name: Main
widget.content:
There are national mandatory and local conditions covering various areas related to the sale of alcohol. Failure to comply with these conditions is an offence that comes with various fines and penalties.

As a member of staff in the licensed trade, you must understand the offences that could be committed under the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 that may affect you both directly and indirectly. Take a look at a few of these offences which might be relevant to you.

- It is an offence to be on a licensed premises
  while drunk or incapable.

- It is an offence to obtain alcohol for a person
  who is drunk.

- It is an offence for staff and managers of a
  licensed premises to be on those premises drunk.

- It is an offence to behave in a disorderly manner
  or use obscene language to the annoyance of
  any person.

- It is an offence to refuse or fail to leave licensed
  premises when asked to do so.

- It is an offence to sell alcohol to trade, other
  than premises which are used exclusively for
  the purpose.
NEXT
BACK

- It is an offence to sell alcohol from moving
  vehicle unless this is expressly permitted
  within the operating plan.

- It is an offence to deliver alcohol from a vehicle
  if a day book and delivery book is not kept.
  These books should record amounts of alcohol due
  for delivery that day and the names and
  addresses of the recipients of the alcohol.

- It is an offence to deliver alcohol to any
  unlicensed premises between the hours of
  midnight and 06:00.

- It is an offence to keep goods which have not
  had duty paid in the licensed premises. The
  licence holder is open to prosecution and all
  goods will be seized and destroyed as the
  court orders.

widget.name: TEXT. Main.
widget.content:
There is lots of evidence to show that, as alcohol becomes more affordable, drinking increases, and as drinking increases so does harm. One of the best ways to reduce the amount of low cost, strong alcohol drunk by people in any country is to make it less affordable. In order to combat this problem, the Scottish government has introduced minimum pricing legislation.

Since the 1st May 2018, it is against the law to sell alcohol any cheaper that 50p per unit in Scotland. Anyone with a licence to sell alcohol will not be allowed to sell it cheaper than this. Therefore, it is a requirement that all staff who sell alcohol are aware of this legislation and do not sell alcohol at a price lower than is legal. This applies to both off-sales and on-sales.

widget.name: TEXT. Title.
widget.content: Minimum Unit Pricing

widget.name: TEXT.1
widget.content: Your Responsibility

widget.name: TEXT.3
widget.content: • The price per unit is 50 pence.

widget.name: TEXT.4
widget.content: • All alcohol must be sold at or above its MUP.

widget.name: TEXT.5
widget.content: • All signage and promotions must be checked so that alcohol is not advertised or sold at a price below MUP.

widget.name: TEXT.6
widget.content: • Any Licensing standards officer or police officers checking the pricing of alcohol products should be provided with whatever reasonable assistance is required.

widget.name: TEXT.7
widget.content: • Any questions should be raised with the DPM or another member of management.

widget.name: TEXT.2
widget.content: Minimum unit pricing is not a tax, it is a targeted way of making sure alcohol is sold at a sensible price. Allowing alcohol to be sold at less than the MUP is a criminal offence under the 2005 Act. In order to comply with MUP the following points must be complied with at all times:

widget.name: TEXT. Main.
widget.content:
Every drink will have a minimum price based on the amount of pure alcohol it contains.
If you're selling alcohol and you don't know the new minimum price of a product, you can use the following formula:

The price per unit (£0.50) x the strength of alcohol (ABV) x the volume in litres

Select the icons below for some examples.

widget.name: TEXT. Title.
widget.content: CALCULATING MUP

widget.name: s2 txt
widget.content: a 700ml bottle of spirits at 37.5% ABV must be sold for no less than £13.13 (£0.50 x 37.5 x 0.7)

widget.name: s3 txt
widget.content: a 750ml bottle of wine at 12% ABV must be sold for no less than £4.50 (£0.50 x 12 x 0.75)

widget.name: s4 txt
widget.content: a 500ml bottle of craft beer at 6% ABV must be sold for no less than £1.50 (£0.50 x 6 x 0.5)

widget.name: s5 txt
widget.content: a 2 litre bottle of cider at 6% ABV must be sold for no less than £6.00 (£0.50 x 6 x 2)

widget.name: s6 txt
widget.content: a 25ml shot of Tequila at 40% ABV must be sold for no less than 50p (£0.50 x 40 x 0.025)

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
You and your customers need to feel safe and secure, and it's your responsibility to have protective security measures in place, but criminal behaviour presents us with a challenge. Would you know what to do in a terrorist attack?

Unfortunately, licensed premises are often seen as targets for criminals. But, by following the best advice from trusted agencies, you can help deter criminal activity and help to keep your customers, guests and colleagues safe.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: Staying Safe and Secure

widget.mainContent:
All new premises license applications require CCTV recording in place. In the event that a serious crime has taken place, on or near to your premises, and where the premises have the benefit of CCTV, filmed evidence will be retained by your manager and immediately handed to the police carrying out any investigation.

It is also essential that every effort is made to preserve the scene of the crime, preferably untouched, and to secure any evidence until the arrival of the police. You should not place yourselves in jeopardy or risk injury.

Ask your manager about your policy in relation to the handling of bomb threats or other major disruptions, which could lead to the evacuation of the premises.

Find out about your search procedure, response to telephone bomb threats, evacuation procedure, safe evacuation distances and assembly points.

You should also be aware of:

  • Code words used by your team to indicate any threat.
  • Your front door vehicle monitoring system.
  • Prompt cards to help you deal with telephone threats.
  • External building checks.
  • How to log suspicious behaviour.

If you or a colleague locate a specific item mentioned within a threat:

  • Do not touch, tilt or tamper with the item.
  • Notify the police immediately and follow the instructions given to you by them.

Thankfully, there are national and international agencies who work hard to counter-terrorism. These experts are here to help. It's good to know that you can contact them if you need advice. You can find out more from the following agencies:

NaCTSO
The National Counter Terrorism Security Office is a police unit that supports the 'protect and prepare' strands of the government’s counter-terrorism strategy.

CPNI
Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure is the United Kingdom government authority which provides protective security advice to businesses and organisations.

Counter-Terrorism Policing
The National Counter Terrorism Policing Network (NCTPN) is the national collaboration of police forces in the United Kingdom working to prevent, deter and investigate terrorism in the United Kingdom.

widget.name: TEXT. Title.
widget.content: SMOKING

widget.name: TEXT.2
widget.content:
The Scottish Government recommends that if a customer smokes in your workplace you should follow these guidelines:

  • advise the customer that smoking is prohibited by law, and ask them to stop.
  • advise them of a place that they can smoke, and point out the non-smoking signs.
  • refuse to serve anyone who continues to smoke.
  • inform your manager if you are unsure of how to deal with a smoker or you have any trouble in doing so.

widget.name: Text. Main
widget.content:
Smoking in Scotland is regulated under the health act and directly affects licensed premises, as smoking is not allowed in any wholly or substantially enclosed public spaces in Scotland, including all bars, hotels, clubs, cafes and restaurants.

Penalties

Your premises can be fined £200 for allowing a customer to smoke, and the person caught smoking can be fined £50. Refusal to pay and comply with the law could lead to prosecution.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
The Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 is in place to ensure that the licensed trade behaves in a responsible and safe manner within the legal framework.

Working in the licensed trade, you have a direct responsibility to uphold these laws and support the licensing objectives.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
children, young people and alcohol
2.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
One of the five objectives of the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 is to protect children from harm. You therefore need to be fully aware of and understand the law surrounding the sale of alcohol to children and young people, as you have a direct duty to uphold this law.

A child is classified as someone who is under 16 years of age.

A young person is classified as someone who is either 16 or 17 years of age.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
CHILDREN, YOUNG
PEOPLE AND ALCOHOL
Click on the tabs or page corners to navigate through the book.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
The Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 aims to protect children and young people from harm.

Select the corner of the book to find out what the law states.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
PROTECTING
CHILDREN FROM HARM
start

Challenge

25

Challenge 25

If you intend to purchase alcohol and appear to be under the age of
25, please do not
be offended if you
are asked for
proof of age.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
You must ensure that the customers you serve alcohol to are adults; this means they are aged 18 or over. It can be difficult to decide on the age of a young person for several reasons:

  • The way a person dresses and behaves can be misleading
  • People in large groups can be harder to identify individually
  • People can become offended if you question their age

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
AGE VERIFICATION
POLICY - CHALLENGE 25

Therefore, it is a legal requirement that all licensed premises have a written age verification policy. This policy should state that any customer who looks under 25 will be required to prove that they are over 18 before they can purchase alcohol.

This is known as 'Challenge 25'. If you serve alcohol to a child or young person you commit an offence, so if you are in any doubt at all, you have a legal responsibility to ask for proof of age. There are few defences for committing this offence; however, you may have a defence:

• If you can show that you had taken reasonable steps to establish their age.
  • If no reasonable person could have suspected from their appearance they were under 18 years of age, and that to establish their age you have asked for an accepted proof of age document.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
To establish a person’s age, you must ask for a legally accepted proof of age document. Your company will have a policy in place that details when to ask for identification and which proof of age documents are accepted. Take a look at some of the proof of age documents that may be accepted by your company.

  • A valid passport
  • A European Union photocard driving licence
  • A PASS ca rd(Proof of Age Standards Scheme)
  • A Ministry of Defence Form 90 [Defence identity card]
  • A national identity card issued by an EU member state other than United Kingdom, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Switzerland
  • A biometric residence permit/card

The policy of some premises is to ask for proof of age if they suspect a person is under 25. Your premises manager will brief you on the policy for your premises.
PROOF OF AGE DOCUMENTS
Passport
PASS Card
Driving Licence

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
In order to check that the law regarding children, young people and alcohol is being upheld, and that those operating in the licensed trade are acting responsibly, the government introduced test purchasing.

Test purchasing is a scheme whereby children and young people are authorised by the police to attempt to buy alcohol in licensed premises. The purpose of this scheme is to ensure that individuals working in licensed premises are adhering to age-related law.
TEST PURCHASING

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content: When it comes to dealing with children, young people and alcohol, it is your responsibility to be totally vigilant. You must ensure that you ask for proof of age from anyone who appears to be under the age of 18. If you cannot be certain you MUST refuse service.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
Alcohol Awareness
3.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Alcohol is classed as a drug because, when consumed, it affects the physical, mental, emotional and behavioural state of the drinker.

Those who sell alcohol should understand the nature of alcohol and be able to make responsible decisions based on good knowledge. It is because we know the effects of alcohol that we must act responsibly in line with licensing law.

Select the icons below to find out more.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: THE EFFECTS OF ALCOHOL
" Moderate drinking can be part of a healthy lifestyle and can contribute to sociability and relaxation "

" Too much alcohol on one occasion or regularly can result in anti-social behaviour and can have serious negative effects
 on health and wellbeing "

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content: As a member of staff in the licensed trade, you have a responsibility for ensuring you dispense alcohol according to the guidelines set out in the Weights and Measures Act 1985.  It is important that all products are dispensed correctly and accurately, as detailed on the right:

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: DISPENSING ALCOHOL

SPIRITS

Served as: 25ml or 35ml or multiples of these
Measure used: Optic or Brim

WINE AND CHAMPAGNE

Served as: 125ml, 175ml and multiples of both. Wine is permitted to be sold in authorised quantities below 75ml.
Measure used: Optic, Lined or Brim

DRAUGHT BEER AND CIDER

Served as: 1/3 pint, 1/2 pint, 2/3 pint or full pint and multiples of 1/2 pint only
Measure used: Lined or Brim

FORTIFIED WINE

Served as: 50ml or 70ml or multiples of these
Measure used: Optic or Brim

If you are unsure about the correct dispense method or quantity for any product always check with your manager.

widget.name: Tittle
widget.content: ALCOHOL STRENGTH

The strength of an alcoholic drink depends on how much alcohol it contains. This is expressed as percentage alcohol by volume, or A.B.V. for short. You should understand the strength of the products you sell.

Select the icons below to find out some common A.B.V's

Wine

varies from
8% to 16% A.B.V.

Spirits

most spirits are
around 40% A.B.V.

Beer & Lager

most beers range from 3% to 5% A.B.V.

However you should be aware that some premium brands have much higher A.B.V. This also applies to cider.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
You can see clearly that the amount of alcohol in beer compared to spirits is very different, but, of course, we consume these types of alcohol in very different measures.

This is why we more often look at the strength of a drink by how many units of alcohol it contains.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: Units OF ALCOHOL

This is calculated by applying the following formula to any alcoholic drink:

Amount of liquid in ml x % abv / 1000 =
number of units of alcohol

Let us look at a large glass of wine, for example:

250ml wine at 12% abv = 250 x 12 / 1000 = 3

So, a large glass of wine contains
3 units of alcohol.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
If we then look at the recommended safe limits of alcohol for people, it helps you to understand the effect the amount of alcohol your customers are consuming may have.

For both men and women:

Moderate drinking over three or more days to a maximum of 14 units per week. It is recommended that some days are alcohol free.

Pregnant women are recommended not to consume alcohol.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: Recommended Safe Amounts of Alcohol

widget.name: TITLE
widget.content: SO WHAT'S IN YOUR DRINK?

widget.name: TEXT.MAIN.INTRO
widget.content: Click on the images below to find out how many units of alcohol are in your favourite drink. Please be aware that this is an approximate guide, as certain brands contain a higher A.B.V. than others, which will have a direct effect on the number of units.
A 330ml alcopop contains 1.4 units
A pint of cider contains 2.5 units
A margarita cocktail contains 3 units
A 25ml Gin & Tonic contains 1 unit

A pint of
standard lager contains 2.8 units

A pint of
premium lager contains 3 units
A 175ml glass of wine contains 2.1 units
A 250ml Glass of wine contains 3 units

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
A person becomes drunk when they consume alcohol faster than the body can eliminate it. The effect of alcohol is dependent on several factors.

Select the icons below to find out more.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
FACTORS DETERMINING
THE EFFECTS OF ALCOHOL

widget.mainContent: How many drinks are consumed, and how strong the drinks are.
The size of the person consuming the alcohol.
Women are often more affected by alcohol than men.
How much food has been consumed before the person began drinking. The presence of food in the stomach slows down the rate at which alcohol enters the blood.

slides.title: Factors Determining the Effects of Alcohol

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
There is no simple way of knowing how much an individual can drink and stay within safe limits, so it is important that, as someone who sells alcohol, you are able to recognise the common signs of drunkenness.

When alcohol is consumed, the body experiences some short term effects almost straight away that increase with levels of drunkenness. Habitual high levels of alcohol consumption can also have some lasting long term effects.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
THE PHYSICAL
EFFECTS OF ALCOHOL

widget.name: Text.2
widget.content: Select below to find out more about the short and long term physical effects of alcohol.
SHORT TERM EFFECTS
LONG TERM EFFECTS

widget.mainContent:
Brain: your brain cells are killed by heavy drinking and may not recover, your memory will be affected, and some will experience long term mental health problems.

Heart: drinking affects the heart, raising your blood pressure and contributing to heart failure and strokes.

Kidneys and liver: organs that try to clean up your system struggle to process the excess alcohol, and heavy drinking can lead to cirrhosis or kidney failure.

Stomach: drinking can cause stomach ulcers and contributes to cancers of the alimentary canal.

Brain: your mental state is altered, your ability to process information is impaired. You lose inhibitions and may feel or act irrationally and be moody

Eyes: your vision may become blurred and you will have trouble focusing.

Mouth: your speech may become slurred and you may say things you would not normally.

Stomach: your stomach becomes irritated by the alcohol and you may feel sick or vomit.

Bladder: you may need to urinate more often and it is possible you will wet yourself.

Legs: you may have problems with balance and may have difficulty walking or standing, you could fall or injure yourself. You could put yourself or others in danger.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: THE WARNING SIGNS

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Clearly, you cannot see some of the longer term effects of alcohol, but in the short term there are very clear physical signs that you should be looking for when serving alcohol that might indicate a person has had enough to drink.

Select the icons below to find out the warning signs.

Physical effects such as slurred speech, glazed eyes, loss of balance
and co-ordination.
Customers asking for large quantities of alcohol at one time.

Irrational behaviour
and rapid changes
of behaviour.
Customers consuming alcohol very quickly.
Nausea and vomiting.

widget.name: TEXT.Main
widget.content:
People respond to alcohol in different ways. It is important that you remain vigilant in looking out for indicators that may suggest someone has had too much to drink.

However, it is important to remember that some of these indicators could be a sign that someone is unwell. If you are worried about a customer, please ask for the support of your manager; do not ignore the problem.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
Social Responsibility and You
4.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
The licensed trade provides jobs for many people and it is an important part of the economy. Your social responsibility is to practice safe drinking. You have a duty to promote safe drinking and to serve alcohol responsibly.

The effects of alcohol are not just physical and they do not just affect the drinker. Excessive drinking can have very negative effects on our society. It's good to know that drinking trends are changing and the demand for low alcohol drinks (up to 1.2% ABV) is on the rise, so you should make good use of the 'No and Low' options on your menu.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: YOUR SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY

widget.name: Text.2
widget.content:
Excessive drinking can lead to:

  • violent and anti-social behaviour
  • criminal activity
  • unplanned sexual activity and consequences such as pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases
  • relationship difficulties and breakdowns
  • employment and financial problems

All of these things on the right put huge pressure on our care and emergency services, not just the police who have to deal with incidents but the hospital staff and support workers who have to deal with the consequences.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Your premises manager has a duty to ensure that all promotions within your premises are in line with licensing objectives.

Under the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005, the price of alcohol can be varied. However, once the price has been varied, it must be set prior to licensing hours at that price for a minimum of 72 hours. Prices can be reduced for longer than 72 hours, but never less. 'Happy hours' are no longer legal.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: ALCOHOL PROMOTIONS

• is targeted at young people, encouraging them to drink
  • encourages anyone to drink more alcohol by way of discounting
  • rewards larger purchases
  • is based around the alcoholic strength of a drink
  • encourages alcohol to be consumed quickly
  • offers unlimited drinking for a set price
  • offers prizes that are alcoholic (unless given in a sealed container for consumption off the premises)

The Licensing [Scotland] Act 2005 makes it clear that irresponsible promotions must not be carried out on licensed premises.

Promotions are seen as irresponsible if it:











All of the objectives of the licensing act are reflected in this new approach to promotions.

widget.name: TEXT.MAIN
widget.content:
Whilst you may not decide on the promotions that run in your place of work, you can help customers make responsible decisions.

Select the icons below to find out how.
Alcohol Promotions - Your Role

widget.mainContent:
• Offer great customer service that will encourage customers to return.
  • Offer your customers choice and value without promoting excessive drinking.
  • Be friendly, efficient and have great product knowledge.
  • Keep your surroundings clean and tidy.

• Discourage fast and excessive drinking.
  • Offer water to help slow down customers that appear to be drinking too much.

• Cut customers off if they have had too much to drink.
  • Never serve a drunk person, as this is a breach of licence and illegal.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
You also play an important role in helping the campaign to tackle drink driving. The legal limit for alcohol in the blood is 50mg per 100mls of blood. It is recommended that you advise customers, if asked, that it is safest not to drink at all when driving, as alcohol affects people differently.

You should also offer a good range of soft drinks and beverages. It can be helpful to have the number of a local taxi company handy so drivers have an alternative way of getting home.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: DRINK DRIVING

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
The achievement of the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 objectives depends on you playing your part by:

  • ensure that your customer service enables people to make responsible decisions
  • understand the impact of excessive drinking
  • refuse service to those who are drunk

You have a duty to act responsibly.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
Drugs in the licensed trade
5.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
The Licensing Act 2005 (Scotland) recognises that, in our society, illegal drugs are an inevitable issue in the licensed trade. It is important to remember that, while not all premises will be affected by drug activity, licensed premises are a natural target for both drug dealers and drug users. The Licensing Act states the importance of a zero-tolerance policy toward drugs.

By being vigilant and recognising the signs of possible drug use and drug dealing, you can help to reduce the likelihood of drugs in your workplace, therefore having a direct impact on the success of the zero-tolerance message. This will help create an environment that is safe for both you and your customers.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
DRUGS IN THE
LICENSED TRADE

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
There is no clear definition of what a drug user should look like. Drug users can be men, women, old, young, well dressed or scruffily dressed. Anyone who comes into your workplace can be a potential drug user, therefore it is important to recognise some of the symptoms associated with drug use.

Of course, some such signs may also indicate excessive alcohol consumption or could be a sign of illness, so you need to exercise caution and judgement. If you are concerned about a customer displaying these symptoms, inform a senior colleague or manager.

Select the numbers on the right to identify four of the most common indicators of drug use.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
PHYSICAL SIGNS
OF DRUG USE

widget.mainContent: Confusion and frequent or rapid changes of behaviour. Agitated and exaggerated behaviour, such as excessive giggling or jerky movements.
Dilated pupils or very small pupils. Watery or bloodshot eyes and a glazed or dazed appearance.
Nose rubbing and sniffing. Traces of powder around the nose area.
Nausea and vomiting. Excessive consumption of soft drinks due to dehydration.

widget.content: 1
2
3
4

widget.name: title
widget.content:
Behavioural signs
of drug activity

widget.name: Text
widget.content: Certain activities can be an indicator of drug use or drug dealing. Select the icons below to find out what you should look out for.

Brief
Encounters
Drug Dealers
Exchanges
list of Names
Loose Talk
Secretive Behaviour
Spiking
Toilet Trips

widget.mainContent: Individuals who appear to be talking to lots of different people briefly, holding court for short periods of time.
Known drug dealers frequenting the premises.
Any exchange of money or packages.
Lists of names and numbers lying around.
Overheard conversations that include references to drugs or drug slang.
Secretive behaviour and subdued conversations.

Drug users and dealers are not easy to identify. It is therefore important to be vigilant at all times, and look for the signs we have described, as they may indicate drug activity. It is important to remember that, in some circumstances, drugs may have been taken without the individual being aware. These incidents are known as 'spiking'.

If you suspect such an incident, or if anyone reports an incident to you, it is very important that you tell your manager immediately.
Anyone making regular trips to the toilet or outside, often followed by a different person each time.

widget.name: TEXT.MAIN
widget.content:
It is useful to be aware of the types of drugs that might be sold or used on licensed premises. If you suspect that you have found any of the following substances, you must inform a manager immediately.

Select the images below for further information:

widget.name: TEXT.HEADING
widget.content:
COMMON TYPES
OF ILLEGAL DRUGS

widget.mainContent:
Appearance
White, yellow, pink or brown powder in self-seal bags, snorted or swallowed.

Possible Evidence
Pipes, tubes, paper wraps, self-seal bags

Physical Signs of Use
Overactive jaw/Dilated pupils/Bad breath/Hyperactivity

Long Term Dangers
Paranoia / High blood pressure / Weight loss

Appearance
Brown, green or black resin smoked in hand-rolled cigarettes.

Possible Evidence
Hand-rolled cigarettes / Torn up beer mats and bits of cardboard used to make roaches

Physical Signs
Loss of inhibition / Relaxant / Short term anxiety and paranoia / Slow reflexes / Dilated pupils

Long Term Dangers
Chest damage / Bronchitis / Lung cancer / Extreme lethargy

Appearance
White powder, usually sniffed and can be injected.

Possible Evidence
Rolled banknotes / Traces of blood or powder on banknotes / Drinking straws found in toilets / Traces of powder on seats or surfaces / Discarded plastic cards

Physical Signs
Runny nose / Frequent visits to the toilet / Irritable or aggressive customers

Long Term Dangers
Addictive and habit forming / Physical damage of nasal passage / Increasing paranoia / Heart damage

Appearance
Brown or white tablets; pink, yellow or clear capsules.

Possible Evidence
Likely to be consumed in privacy, normally sold individually in cellophane bags

Physical Signs
Dilated pupils / Tightened jaw / Nausea / Sweating / Poor coordination / Overheating

Long Term Dangers
Respiratory collapse / Heart failure / Anxiety and paranoia / Possible brain damage

Appearance
Comes as colourless, odourless liquid in small bottles or capsules. Sometimes used to 'spike' drinks.

Possible Evidence
Discarded small bottles

Physical Signs
Drowsiness / Sedated appearance / Sometimes euphoric

Long Term Dangers
Vomiting / Fits / Collapse / Loss of muscle control

Appearance
White or brown speckled powder in paper wraps; can be sniffed or injected.

Possible Evidence
Syringes / Spoons, lighters and foil

Physical Signs
Vomiting / Yellowed complexion / Runny nose / Drowsiness

Long Term Dangers
Highly addictive / Death by overdose

widget.name: TEXT.TITLE
widget.content: Preventing Drug Activity

widget.name: TEXT.INTRO
widget.content:
In supporting the policy of zero tolerance to drugs, there are some simple steps that you can take to deter the drug use and drug dealing in your workplace.

It is important to ensure all staff are trained on how to prevent drug activity and use in your premises.

Select the numbers from the picture on the right to identify six deterrents to drug activity.

ALWAYS REMEMBER TO...

- Remain vigilant at all times to possible dealers or users.

- Never turn a blind eye as this is viewed as permitting.

- Stay calm when faced with possible drug activity.

- Ensure such people are ejected from your premises.

- Refuse future entry to such people.
Start
1
2
3
4
5
6

widget.mainContent: Keep the bar and tables clean and clear.
Support any initiatives your workplace has to control and prevent drug use. Report any incidents to your manager.
Carry out frequent toilet checks.
Be vigilant and alert at all times.
Clear drinks left unattended to decrease risk of “spiking”.
Maintain good standards of hygiene in the bar, keeping it clear and tidy.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Drugs are a serious danger to our society, damaging both public health and social structures.

They contribute towards aggressive behaviour and conflict. For these reasons, you should remember to uphold a zero-tolerance policy at all times.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
Conflict in your workplace
6.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Conflict in your workplace should be infrequent. Those premises that do become linked with conflict will often lose business, attract problem customers and increase the potential for further conflict. While the majority of licensed premises are unlikely to have to deal with conflict situations of a serious nature, there will, however, always be the potential for drunken customers or minor altercations.

It is therefore important to do all you can to prevent conflict situations and be aware of how best to deal with such situations.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
CONFLICT IN
YOUR WORKPLACE

Problems with conflict in the licensed trade can be directed against the premises, customers, management and, of course, the staff.

The conflict may be an isolated incident or a series of connected incidents linked to:

  • drug dealing
  • organised crime or feuds
  • excessive drinking
  • bad tempers and stubbornness
  • arguments
  • complaints

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
It is important to stay aware of the various signs that may indicate conflict.

So what should we look out for?

Select the icons below to find out.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SIGNS OF CONFLICT
Raised voices
?#&Swearing*%!
Large Groups gathering
Annoyed or concerned looking customers

A Distraction causing heads
to turn
The sound of breaking glass or falling furniture

widget.src: Montpeliers Edinburgh Ltd-Flow-4Y7Z0302-Photograph by Angus Bremner copy.jpg

widget.name: TEXT.TITLE
widget.content: CAUSES OF CONFLICT

widget.name: TEXT.MAIN.
widget.content: Conflict can be caused by various factors. Being aware of these factors and how to impact on them can contribute to avoiding conflict. If you remain vigilant and deal with the first sign of conflict as early as possible, the less likely it is to turn into a really difficult situation. Select the icons below to discover the causes of conflict.
Undesirable Customers
Lack of Communication
Unresolved problems

Poor
Atmosphere
Product

Unhelpful
staff

Poor
service
Drunkenness

widget.mainContent: It is important to ensure that known criminals and troublemakers are not permitted to drink on your premises, as this may invite conflict.

Good communication is vital in avoiding conflict. It is essential to ensure management, staff and security personnel keep each other informed at all times.

It is also important to communicate effectively with your customers and pass on any feedback they may give you. Keeping your customers informed will allay concerns and tempers, and help avoid potential conflict.

Problems that are not dealt with quickly will not go away; they will only get worse. If solutions are not found before the situation deteriorates, then things can spiral out of control, leading to potentially serious conflict.
If customers feel uncomfortable or unsafe they can become jumpy or irritated, which can lead to anything from minor niggles to serious arguments between customers or towards staff.
Customers want value for money and can become angry if they receive poor quality products. This can lead to complaints which, may become heated.
Unhelpful staff can be very irritating to customers, resulting in tempers becoming frayed and arguments breaking out.
Customers can become very frustrated when receiving poor service. This can lead to short tempers, arguments and complaints.
You have a responsibility to refuse service to drunken individuals, as they can become argumentative and aggressive towards other customers or staff.

widget.src: Montpeliers Edinburgh Ltd-Flow-4Y7Z0292-Photograph by Angus Bremner.jpg
widget.name: background-image
TEXT. Main
widget.content:
As we said, a lack of communication can cause conflict. It is essential, therefore, to use your communication skills effectively in order to minimise the risk of conflict.

It is a proven fact that, when communicating with those around you, the message you give out is shown on the chart below.

Being aware of both what you say and, more importantly, how you say it can help you communicate clearly and effectively with your customers, and be very helpful if you find yourself faced with an angry or frustrated customer.

Select each section of the chart to find out how your message is broken down.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: COMMUNICATION SKILLS

The words you
say account for 7%
of the total message

The tone of voice we
use accounts for 38% of the total message
The body language you display accounts for a huge 55% of the total message
7%
38%
55%

widget.name: TEXT.MAIN
widget.content:
Developing a Conflict Strategy

There are, however, steps that can be taken to prevent conflict. By having a conflict strategy in place, conflict situations can be reduced or avoided. It is a good idea to talk this over with your premises manager as soon as possible (perhaps at a staff meeting) to ensure you are aware of how you can contribute to the success of this strategy.

Select the icons below to find out what information should be included in a good conflict strategy.

widget.name: TEXT.TITLE
widget.content: PREVENTING CONFLICT

widget.mainContent:
A conflict strategy should detail information on any relevant local information, such as:

Customer base - this would give details on customers who use, or try to use, the premises, but may potentially cause conflict, such as troublemakers, known criminals, drug dealers and users, etc.

Local events - this would highlight any events happening in the local area that could potentially cause conflict, such as sporting events, protest marches, bank holidays, concerts, etc.

Taking good care of your customers will go a long way to preventing conflict. Therefore, a good conflict strategy will focus on how customers should be handled and should include information on:

Customer service policy - which should provide clear guidelines on service standards and timings.

Communication structure - which should state clearly how information should be passed on to both colleagues and customers.

Complaints procedure - clear guidelines should be stated on how to handle complaints effectively to prevent situations escalating.

Prevention of conflict must be managed. There must be a number of measures that should be in place to help avoid conflict.

Zero tolerance policy - a zero tolerance approach to both violence and drugs should be in place in your workplace. How to deal with violent or drug-related incidents should be clearly stated.

Drinking up times and procedures - this must be clear to both staff and customers.

CCTV and premises monitoring - your employer has a responsibility to keep your workplace safe and secure. There should be sufficient monitoring in place to act as both a conflict deterrent and a means of evidence, should conflict arise.

Local police liaison - it is vital in preventing conflict to have good working relationship with the local police. A conflict strategy should support local police initiatives.

widget.content:
Unfortunately, not every conflict situation can be avoided. In most cases, you would not be expected to deal directly with such situations, as your safety is very important, but you should inform a senior colleague or manager as soon as possible.

If, however, you are the first point of contact with a customer in a conflict situation, the way in which you behave can make a huge difference to the outcome. It can be easy to make simple mistakes that may actually make the situation worse.

By adhering to the guidelines in the following video you can avoid this.

DEALING WITH
A CONFLICT SITUATION
Click on the tabs or page corners to navigate through the book.

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
As the video demonstrated, there are certain guidelines that should be followed when faced with a conflict situation

Select the corner of the book to review the recommended guidelines.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content:
GUIDELINES FOR
DEALING WITH CONFLICT
Start

widget.name: TEXT. Main
widget.content:
Hopefully, you will rarely or never have to deal with a serious incident in your workplace. However, if you do, always remember that your safety is paramount. You must remain calm and inform a manager of any problems or potential problems as soon as possible.

Discuss your workplace conflict strategy with your manager when you return to work.

widget.name: TEXT. Title
widget.content: SUMMARY
